oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Interview - Tony Russell - 2005-05-26
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Interview moderated by Robert K. Oermann with author Tony Russell about his book Country Music Records: A Discography, 1921-1942 from the Ford Theater at the Country Music Hall of Fame and Museum on May 26, 2005.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Robert K. Oermann; Tony Russell;
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: Includes audio from video and questions from the audience. Interview moderated by Robert K. Oermann. Recording begins in progress / (00:00) Jay Orr introduces Bob Oermann and Tony Russell / (03:35) Oermann's introductory comments / (04:45) Russell talks about how he became interested in old time music / (08:12) Plays excerpt of recording of Take A Drink On Me by Charlie Poole and the North Carolina Ramblers / (09:10) Tony continues talking about his early interest in old time music / (10:30) Oermann talks about his discovery of the magazine Old Time Music and asks Tony how it came about / (13:34) Question about the genesis of the country music discography / (15:10) Finding support for the creation of the book and talk about Bob Pinson's input / (17:40) Comments about the process of putting the discography and sessionography together / (20:50) Assets used to pull information together /

(22:50) Oermann mentions the many pseudonyms of Vernon Dalhart and the problem researching artists of his stature and including them / (25:55) Ease in recognizing Dalhart recordings and consequently more of his pseudonyms / (28:57) Oermann's recollections of Russell's research and asks about the pleasure of listening to recordings / (30:20) Tony talks about Bernard "Slim" Smith, seeking him out and the information gleaned from him / (35:39) Talks about seeking out members of Freeny's Barn Dance Band and plays recording of Sullivan's Hollow / (39:02) Relative absence of old time recordings made in Nashville / (40:20) Nashville recordings of the Binkley Brothers Dixie Clodhoppers and the Vaughn Quartet / (42:15) Question from the audience about what is considered the first country music old time recording and why the discography stops in 1942/ (44:58) Comments about African American , comedy and gag old time recordings /
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Oermann, Robert K.; Russell, Tony; Country Music Hall of Fame & Museum (Nashville, Tenn.);
